required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Randomized Phase IIa Efficacy and Safety Study of Radium-223 Dichloride With Abiraterone Acetate or Enzalutamide in Metastatic Castration-resistant Prostate Cancer (CRPC)
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Open-label Phase IIa Study Evaluating the Efficacy and Safety of Radium-223 Dichloride in Combination With Abiraterone Acetate or Enzalutamide in Subjects With CRPC Who Have Bone Metastases

oversight_info.authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

brief_summary.textblock: In the present study, the potential for added clinical benefit and safety of radium-223 dichloride in combination with abiraterone acetate or enzalutamide will be investigated evaluating radiological progression free survival, overall survival, and skeletal events. This study will also explore the clinical utility of different imaging modalities (whole body technetium-99 bone scan, diffusion-weighted MRI, and sodium fluoride PETCT scan) in assessing bone lesions in subjects with CRPC and bone metastases being treated with radium- 223 dichloride. All patients involved in the study will be randomized (assigned by chance) into one of three arms: radium-223 dichloride 50 kBq/kg administered every 4 weeks; radium-223 dichloride 50 kBq/kg administered every 4 weeks together with abiraterone acetate 1000 mg orally daily plus prednisone 5 mg orally twice daily; and radium-223 dichloride 50 kBq/kg administered every 4 weeks together with enzalutamide 160 mg orally daily. The study will be conducted in the United States. The study will consist of screening, treatment, and follow-up. Study treatment will continue until disease progression as determined by investigator or when the patient meets criteria for withdrawal from study. Follow-up will continue until patient dies, is lost to follow-up, or withdraws informed consent. Active followup will continue up to 2 years following last dose of radium-223 dichloride. Long-term follow-up for survival and treatment-related safety events will continue up to 7 years following last dose of radium-223 dichloride.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.time_frame: From randomization to radiological disease progression or death from any cause, up to 30 months

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to first symptomatic skeletal event(SSE)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From ransomization to the first SSE, up to 30 months
From randomization to the earlier of first SSE or death, up to 30 months
From randomization to the date of radiological disease progression, up to 30 months
From randomization to the date of radiological bone progression, up to 30 months
From randomization to the date of radiological progression, up to 30 months

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with treatment-emergent adverse events as a measure of safety and tolerability
Number of participants with serious adverse events as a measure of safety and tolerability

intervention.description: Radium-223 dichloride (Xofigo, BAY88-8223) 50 kBq/kg every 4 weeks x 6 doses intravenous injection (slow bolus)
Abiraterone acetate 1000 mg (4 x 250 mg tablets) taken orally once daily
Prednisone 5 mg capsule taken orally twice daily
Enzalutamide 160 mg (4 x 40 mg tablets) taken orally once daily

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Histologically or cytologically confirmed adenocarcinoma of the prostate
- Known castration-resistant disease
- Serum Prostate specific antigen (PSA) ≥5 ng/mL (μg/L)
- Multiple skeletal metastases (≥ 2 hot spots) on bone scan
- Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status (PS) 0 to 2
- Adequate hematologic, hepatic, and renal function
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of visceral metastasis, or visceral metastases
- Malignant lymphadenopathy with lymph nodes exceeding 3 cm in short axis diameter
- Medical condition that would make prednisone (corticosteroid) use contraindicated
- Any chronic medical condition requiring a higher dose of corticosteroid than 5 mg prednisone bid
- Treatment with more than one chemotherapy agent for prostate cancer
- Prior systemic radiotherapy and hemibody external radiotherapy
- History of pituitary or adrenal dysfunction
- Chronic conditions associated with non-malignant abnormal bone growth (e.g., confirmed Paget's disease of bone)
- Atrial fibrillation, or other cardiac arrhythmia requiring medical therapy
- History of seizures (taking/not taking anticonvulsants), arteriovenous malformation in the brain, head trauma with loss of consciousness
- Central nervous system(CNS) metastasis
